title: How to Make Chamomile Tea Popsicles

steps.headline: Bring the water to a boil in a small saucepan.
steps.description: This will be enough to make about 10 popsicles. Keep in mind that the exact number depends on the size of your popsicle molds; each design will have a slightly different holding capacity.

steps.headline: Take the saucepan off the stove, then stir in the honey.
steps.description: Chamomile popsicles are great for teething children, but if you are making these for a child under 1 year of age, do not add the honey.

steps.headline: Add the tea bags, cover the saucepan with a lid, then let the tea steep for 10 minutes.
steps.description: You can also use ¼ cup and 1 tablespoon (6 grams) of fresh chamomile flowers instead.

steps.headline: Fill the popsicle molds with the tea.
steps.description: Leave about ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter) of head space so that the tea can expand as it freezes. If you used loose chamomile flowers, pour the tea through a strainer into another saucepan first, and discard the flowers.

steps.headline: Wipe the top of the mold dry with a paper towel, then insert the popsicle sticks.
steps.description: Each popsicle mold will be a little different. Some of them come with a lid that already has sticks attach. Some come with a lid that has slots for popsicles sticks in it. If your mold has a slotted lid, pop the lid on first, then insert the popsicle sticks.

steps.headline: Place the popsicles into the freezer for at least 8 hours.
steps.description: It would be best to let these freeze overnight, however. Once again, the freezing time will vary, depending on the size of your popsicle molds.

steps.headline: Serve the popsicles.
steps.description: To de-mold the popsicles, hold the mold under running water for a few moments, then pull them out. You can store the popsicles in a plastic container between sheets of parchment paper. You can also place them into individual freezer bags. They will last 1 week.

steps.headline: Place the herbs into a large mug.
steps.description: If you don't like hibiscus, use 3 tablespoons of chamomile flowers instead. The mug needs to be big enough to hold 1¼ (300 milliliters) of water.

steps.headline: Fill the mug with boiling water, and let it steep for 5 minutes.
steps.description: If you can, place a small plate over the mug to keep the tea hot. This will allow the honey to melt easier.

steps.headline: Pour the tea through a strainer into a bowl.
steps.description: You can also use a small saucepan or a clean mug instead. Discard whatever is left in the strainer.

steps.headline: Stir in the honey, salt, and lemon juice.
steps.description: How much honey you stir in depends on how sweet you'd like the popsicles. Keep in mind that the yogurt you will be using is plain and unflavored, so it might be a good idea to make it on the sweeter side.

steps.headline: Allow the tea to cool, then stir in the yogurt.
steps.description: Keep stirring the yogurt until it mixes in evenly with the tea. The texture should be consistent, with not streaks or swirls.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into your popsicle molds.
steps.description: Leave ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter) so that the mixture can expand as it freezes.

steps.headline: Wipe the top of the molds clean, then insert the tops.
steps.description: Some popsicle molds already have sticks attached. Some molds don't, and you need to insert the popsicle sticks yourself.

steps.headline: Freeze the popsicles for at least 8 hours.
steps.description: Keep in mind that the popsicles may take a little bit more/less time depending on the size of the molds.

steps.headline: Serve the popsicles.
steps.description: De-mold the popsicles by holding the mold under running water for a few moments, then pulling them out. Store any leftover popsicles in a plastic container between sheets of parchment paper. You can also place them into separate freezer bags. They will last 1 week.

steps.headline: Boil the water.
steps.description: Pour the water into a small saucepan, then bring it to a boil over medium heat. This will be enough to make about 6 popsicles. Keep in mind, however, that the exact amount will depend on how big or small your popsicle molds are.

steps.headline: Add the tea bag, and let it steep for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Keep the saucepan covered with a lid during this time.

steps.headline: Take the tea bag out, then let the tea cool to room temperature.
steps.description: This will allow it to freeze faster. If you are in a hurry, you can place the saucepan into an ice bath, and stir the tea as it cools. These popsicles are intended for teething babies. If you wish to make the popsicles for yourself, you can sweeten them with some honey. Do not give any popsicles containing honey to children under 1 year of age.

steps.headline: Pour the tea into the popsicle molds two-thirds of the way.
steps.description: You will be filling the rest of the space up with strawberry puree to create pretty, two-color popsicles.

steps.headline: Puree the strawberries.
steps.description: Rinse the strawberries first, then chop off the stems. Cut them into smaller pieces, then puree them in a blender or food processor until they turn into a chunky liquid.

steps.headline: Pour the strawberry puree into the popsicle molds, filling them the rest of the way.
steps.description: Try to leave about ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter) of space at the top so that the liquid can expand as it freezes.

steps.headline: Wipe the top of the mold clean, then insert the lid.
steps.description: Some popsicle molds already have sticks attached to the lid part. Some molds have slots in the lids instead. If your lid has slots in it, pop the lids on first, then insert some popsicle sticks.

steps.headline: Freeze the popsicles for at least 8 hours.
steps.description: The exact freezing time will vary depending on the size of the popsicle mold. The bigger the popsicle mold is, the longer it will take to freeze.

steps.headline: Serve the popsicles.
steps.description: To take the popsicles out of the mold, hold the mold under running water for a few moments, then pull the popsicles out. Store the popsicles in a plastic container between sheets of parchment paper. You can also stick them into individual freezer bags. They will last 1 week.

text: Making Honey-Chamomile Popsicles Bring the water to a boil in a small saucepan. This will be enough to make about 10 popsicles. Keep in mind that the exact number depends on the size of your popsicle molds; each design will have a slightly different holding capacity. Take the saucepan off the stove, then stir in the honey. Chamomile popsicles are great for teething children, but if you are making these for a child under 1 year of age, do not add the honey. Add the tea bags, cover the saucepan with a lid, then let the tea steep for 10 minutes. You can also use ¼ cup and 1 tablespoon (6 grams) of fresh chamomile flowers instead. Fill the popsicle molds with the tea. Leave about ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter) of head space so that the tea can expand as it freezes. If you used loose chamomile flowers, pour the tea through a strainer into another saucepan first, and discard the flowers. Wipe the top of the mold dry with a paper towel, then insert the popsicle sticks. Each popsicle mold will be a little different. Some of them come with a lid that already has sticks attach. Some come with a lid that has slots for popsicles sticks in it. If your mold has a slotted lid, pop the lid on first, then insert the popsicle sticks. Place the popsicles into the freezer for at least 8 hours. It would be best to let these freeze overnight, however. Once again, the freezing time will vary, depending on the size of your popsicle molds. Serve the popsicles. To de-mold the popsicles, hold the mold under running water for a few moments, then pull them out. You can store the popsicles in a plastic container between sheets of parchment paper. You can also place them into individual freezer bags. They will last 1 week. Making Creamy Chamomile Popsicles Place the herbs into a large mug. If you don't like hibiscus, use 3 tablespoons of chamomile flowers instead. The mug needs to be big enough to hold 1¼ (300 milliliters) of water. Fill the mug with boiling water, and let it steep for 5 minutes. If you can, place a small plate over the mug to keep the tea hot. This will allow the honey to melt easier. Pour the tea through a strainer into a bowl. You can also use a small saucepan or a clean mug instead. Discard whatever is left in the strainer. Stir in the honey, salt, and lemon juice. How much honey you stir in depends on how sweet you'd like the popsicles. Keep in mind that the yogurt you will be using is plain and unflavored, so it might be a good idea to make it on the sweeter side. Allow the tea to cool, then stir in the yogurt. Keep stirring the yogurt until it mixes in evenly with the tea. The texture should be consistent, with not streaks or swirls. Pour the mixture into your popsicle molds. Leave ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter) so that the mixture can expand as it freezes. Wipe the top of the molds clean, then insert the tops. Some popsicle molds already have sticks attached. Some molds don't, and you need to insert the popsicle sticks yourself. Freeze the popsicles for at least 8 hours. Keep in mind that the popsicles may take a little bit more/less time depending on the size of the molds. Serve the popsicles. De-mold the popsicles by holding the mold under running water for a few moments, then pulling them out. Store any leftover popsicles in a plastic container between sheets of parchment paper. You can also place them into separate freezer bags. They will last 1 week. Strawberry-Chamomile Teething Popsicles Boil the water. Pour the water into a small saucepan, then bring it to a boil over medium heat. This will be enough to make about 6 popsicles. Keep in mind, however, that the exact amount will depend on how big or small your popsicle molds are. Add the tea bag, and let it steep for 5 minutes. Keep the saucepan covered with a lid during this time. Take the tea bag out, then let the tea cool to room temperature. This will allow it to freeze faster. If you are in a hurry, you can place the saucepan into an ice bath, and stir the tea as it cools. These popsicles are intended for teething babies. If you wish to make the popsicles for yourself, you can sweeten them with some honey. Do not give any popsicles containing honey to children under 1 year of age. Pour the tea into the popsicle molds two-thirds of the way. You will be filling the rest of the space up with strawberry puree to create pretty, two-color popsicles. Puree the strawberries. Rinse the strawberries first, then chop off the stems. Cut them into smaller pieces, then puree them in a blender or food processor until they turn into a chunky liquid. Pour the strawberry puree into the popsicle molds, filling them the rest of the way. Try to leave about ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter) of space at the top so that the liquid can expand as it freezes. Wipe the top of the mold clean, then insert the lid. Some popsicle molds already have sticks attached to the lid part. Some molds have slots in the lids instead. If your lid has slots in it, pop the lids on first, then insert some popsicle sticks. Freeze the popsicles for at least 8 hours. The exact freezing time will vary depending on the size of the popsicle mold. The bigger the popsicle mold is, the longer it will take to freeze. Serve the popsicles. To take the popsicles out of the mold, hold the mold under running water for a few moments, then pull the popsicles out. Store the popsicles in a plastic container between sheets of parchment paper. You can also stick them into individual freezer bags. They will last 1 week.
sentences: Making Honey-Chamomile Popsicles Bring the water to a boil in a small saucepan.
This will be enough to make about 10 popsicles.
Keep in mind that the exact number depends on the size of your popsicle molds; each design will have a slightly different holding capacity.
Take the saucepan off the stove, then stir in the honey.
Chamomile popsicles are great for teething children, but if you are making these for a child under 1 year of age, do not add the honey.
Add the tea bags, cover the saucepan with a lid, then let the tea steep for 10 minutes.
You can also use ¼ cup and 1 tablespoon (6 grams) of fresh chamomile flowers instead.
Fill the popsicle molds with the tea.
Leave about ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter) of head space so that the tea can expand as it freezes.
If you used loose chamomile flowers, pour the tea through a strainer into another saucepan first, and discard the flowers.
Wipe the top of the mold dry with a paper towel, then insert the popsicle sticks.
Each popsicle mold will be a little different.
Some of them come with a lid that already has sticks attach.
Some come with a lid that has slots for popsicles sticks in it.
If your mold has a slotted lid, pop the lid on first, then insert the popsicle sticks.
Place the popsicles into the freezer for at least 8 hours.
It would be best to let these freeze overnight, however.
Once again, the freezing time will vary, depending on the size of your popsicle molds.
Serve the popsicles.
To de-mold the popsicles, hold the mold under running water for a few moments, then pull them out.
You can store the popsicles in a plastic container between sheets of parchment paper.
You can also place them into individual freezer bags.
They will last 1 week.
Making Creamy Chamomile Popsicles Place the herbs into a large mug.
If you don't like hibiscus, use 3 tablespoons of chamomile flowers instead.
The mug needs to be big enough to hold 1¼ (300 milliliters) of water.
Fill the mug with boiling water, and let it steep for 5 minutes.
If you can, place a small plate over the mug to keep the tea hot.
This will allow the honey to melt easier.
Pour the tea through a strainer into a bowl.
You can also use a small saucepan or a clean mug instead.
Discard whatever is left in the strainer.
Stir in the honey, salt, and lemon juice.
How much honey you stir in depends on how sweet you'd like the popsicles.
Keep in mind that the yogurt you will be using is plain and unflavored, so it might be a good idea to make it on the sweeter side.
Allow the tea to cool, then stir in the yogurt.
Keep stirring the yogurt until it mixes in evenly with the tea.
The texture should be consistent, with not streaks or swirls.
Pour the mixture into your popsicle molds.
Leave ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter) so that the mixture can expand as it freezes.
Wipe the top of the molds clean, then insert the tops.
Some popsicle molds already have sticks attached.
Some molds don't, and you need to insert the popsicle sticks yourself.
Freeze the popsicles for at least 8 hours.
Keep in mind that the popsicles may take a little bit more/less time depending on the size of the molds.
Serve the popsicles.
De-mold the popsicles by holding the mold under running water for a few moments, then pulling them out.
Store any leftover popsicles in a plastic container between sheets of parchment paper.
You can also place them into separate freezer bags.
They will last 1 week.
Strawberry-Chamomile Teething Popsicles Boil the water.
Pour the water into a small saucepan, then bring it to a boil over medium heat.
This will be enough to make about 6 popsicles.
Keep in mind, however, that the exact amount will depend on how big or small your popsicle molds are.
Add the tea bag, and let it steep for 5 minutes.
Keep the saucepan covered with a lid during this time.
Take the tea bag out, then let the tea cool to room temperature.
This will allow it to freeze faster.
If you are in a hurry, you can place the saucepan into an ice bath, and stir the tea as it cools.
These popsicles are intended for teething babies.
If you wish to make the popsicles for yourself, you can sweeten them with some honey.
Do not give any popsicles containing honey to children under 1 year of age.
Pour the tea into the popsicle molds two-thirds of the way.
You will be filling the rest of the space up with strawberry puree to create pretty, two-color popsicles.
Puree the strawberries.
Rinse the strawberries first, then chop off the stems.
Cut them into smaller pieces, then puree them in a blender or food processor until they turn into a chunky liquid.
Pour the strawberry puree into the popsicle molds, filling them the rest of the way.
Try to leave about ⅛-inch (0.32-centimeter) of space at the top so that the liquid can expand as it freezes.
Wipe the top of the mold clean, then insert the lid.
Some popsicle molds already have sticks attached to the lid part.
Some molds have slots in the lids instead.
If your lid has slots in it, pop the lids on first, then insert some popsicle sticks.
Freeze the popsicles for at least 8 hours.
The exact freezing time will vary depending on the size of the popsicle mold.
The bigger the popsicle mold is, the longer it will take to freeze.
Serve the popsicles.
To take the popsicles out of the mold, hold the mold under running water for a few moments, then pull the popsicles out.
Store the popsicles in a plastic container between sheets of parchment paper.
You can also stick them into individual freezer bags.
They will last 1 week.
